Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Story: I was behind the wheel, my taxi crawling through a maze of orange cones and impatient drivers. The construction had squeezed the road into a single lane, and just ahead, a school zone sign flashed. Kids clustered near the curb, some darting dangerously close to the street. My phone buzzed in the cupholder—my friend’s name lit up the screen. He’d texted earlier, panicked about assembling his new bookshelf, and now he was calling for a quick video chat. I knew he was struggling, probably surrounded by scattered screws and half-built shelves, counting on me to help him out of his jam. But as a taxi driver, I couldn’t risk even a glance at my phone, not with children so close and the road so tight. My friend expected me to be there for him, to drop everything and help, but my responsibility to my passengers and the kids outside demanded my full attention. My heart pounded as the phone vibrated again, torn between the urge to answer and the duty to keep everyone safe.
